Authors:
Sigrid Liede-Schumann, Sebastian Reuss, Ulrich Meve, Gildas
Gâteblé, Tatyana Livshultz, Paul I. Forster, Livia Wanntorp, Michele
Rodda
Title:
Phylogeny of Marsdenieae (Apocynaceae, Asclepiadoideae) based
on chloroplast and nuclear loci, and a conspectus of the genera
Journal: Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society
Keywords:
classification, evolution, genus circumscription,
systematics, taxonomy
Abstract:
A densely sampled molecular phylogenetic analysis of
Marsdenieae is presented. This tribe is a pan-tropical, predominantly
forest-dwelling lineage of about 730 species. Most Marsdenieae species
are suffrutescent twiners or lianas with the notable exception of Hoya
(350  450 spp.) and Dischidia (ca. 80 spp.), species of which are mostly
succulent epiphytic vines. The circumscription of Marsdenia has been
particularly problematic and variable ranging from Marsdenia sensu
Bullock (with less than 10 Asian species closely related to the type, M.
tinctoria) to Marsdenia sensu Forster (with ca. 300 species included and
distributed throughout the range of the tribe, including the segregate
genera Gongronema, Stephanotis, Dregea, Wattakaka, Leichhardtia,
Cionura, and Gymnema in synonoymy). We sequenced parts of the
chloroplast (trnT-trnF introns and spacers rps16 intron and trnH-psbA
spacer) and two single copy nuclear loci (At2g06530a and At2g34620b) as
well as the Internal Transcribed Spacer (ITS) from 215 accessions,
thought to represent 169 species from 21 of the 29 genera recognized by
Omlor as well as outgroups from the other three tribes. In parsimony and
likelihood analyses, Marsdenia sensu lato is highly polyphyletic,
divided among three primary clades: 1) a well-supported Australasian
Clade that includes the epiphytes Dischidia and Hoya and a number of
Marsdenia species, among them the type species M. tinctoria; 2) a
likewise well-supported Cosmopolitan Clade that includes the rest of
Marsdenieae with several moderately to well-supported subclades that
span the entire distribution range of Marsdenieae, and (3) a poorly
supported clade comprising the relictual genera Rhyssolobium (South
Africa) and Sicyocarpus (Madagascar). All American species of Marsdenia
form a monophyletic sub-clade of the Cosmopolitan Clade. A monophyletic
Marsdenia sensu lato would subsume all species of Marsdenieae. We
discuss alternative classifications that maintain Dischidia and Hoya as
distinct genera and morphological characters that can be used to
diagnose subclades of this phylogeny. Twenty-five new combinations, one
new name, and four new synoynyms are proposed; and two neotypes and 14
lectotypes have been selected.
